entry.title: Regional Structure/City File for Business partner SAP Cloud Public Edition CE2508
entry.content:
To report sales to the tax authorities of each country through electronic invoicing (non-localized), the XML requires certain fields in the customer address, such as Province, District, and Canton. These fields must be numeric, each one dependent on the other, and each with its corresponding descriptive text.

In the configuration environment, the option ‚ÄúSet Country-Specific Checks‚Äù (ID 102592) was activated, but no visible changes can be seen in the Maintain Business Partner or Manage Business Partner (F3163) apps.
In addition, it is necessary to identify an application that allows the joint maintenance of Regions, Provinces, Postal Codes, and Districts, which is required to complete address information in compliance with local fiscal requirements; that is, functionality equivalent to transaction SR12 in the private cloud.

Countries: Costa Rica (CR) and El Salvador (SV)

entry.title: Re: Accounting entries for Price difference , cash discou...
entry.content:
Hello @nagakumari ,

-OBYC determines automatic account postings between MM and FI (BSX, WRX, PRD, FR1, etc.).
-OB09 controls exchange rate difference accounts.
-OBB8 and payment terms define cash discount logic.
-GR/IR clearing ensures matching between goods receipt and invoice receipt quantities and values.
-Freight clearing applies to planned delivery costs or service POs for transport vendors.

Below are the accounting entries :-

 

StepBusiness ScenarioDebit (Dr)Credit (Cr)Explanation / Notes
PO CreationAll Scenarios‚Äî‚ÄîNo accounting entry at PO creation.
Goods Receipt (GR)StandardInventory (BSX)GR/IR (WRX)Stock received, not yet invoiced.
 Price DifferenceInventory (BSX)GR/IR (WRX)GR valued at PO price. Price diff arises later at IR.
 Cash DiscountInventory (BSX)GR/IR (WRX)GR valued at PO price. Discount affects payment later.
 Exchange Rate DifferenceInventory (BSX)GR/IR (WRX)Valued at exchange rate on GR date.
 Freight ClearingInventory (BSX) or Freight Clearing (FR1)GR/IR (WRX)Freight conditions may be planned delivery costs.
Invoice Receipt (IR)StandardGR/IR (WRX)VendorClears GR/IR, posts liability.
 Price DifferenceGR/IR (WRX) Price Difference (PRD)VendorIf invoice ‚â† PO price, difference to PRD.
 Cash DiscountGR/IR (WRX)VendorSame as standard. Discount handled on payment.
 Exchange Rate DifferenceGR/IR (WRX) Exchange Rate Diff (KDM)VendorRevaluation at invoice rate.
 Freight ClearingGR/IR (WRX) Freight Clearing (FR1)VendorFor planned or unplanned freight costs.
Payment to VendorStandardVendorBankClears liability.
 Price DifferenceVendorBankSame as standard.
 Cash DiscountVendorBank Cash Discount (SKT)Discount income posted (SKT) if early payment.
 Exchange Rate DifferenceVendor Exchange Rate Diff (KDF)BankRealized gain/loss on payment date.
 Freight ClearingVendorBankPayment to freight vendor or main vendor.


If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

AspectStandard BehaviorEditable?Where to Enter / NotesWorkaround / Recommendation
Reason Column (Line Item)Displayed in PI document item table‚ùå NoN/A ‚Äì line item field is non-editableCannot enter here; only for display/reporting
Reason at Header LevelHeader field for the PI document‚úÖ Yes (if configured)Use ‚ÄúReason for Difference / Reason Code‚Äù in document headerBest practice: always enter reason at header level for reporting and reconciliation
Line-level ReasonNot available in standard Cloud‚ùå NoN/ACan create Custom Field via Key User Extensibility to capture line-level reason if business requires
PurposeCapture reason for inventory differenceN/AReporting, analytics, reconciliationGL postings do not require line-level reason; header-level reason is sufficient
During PostingReason field not editable‚ùå NoHeader-level reason carries through to FI postingsFor line-level reporting, use custom field or offline reporting logic

entry.title: Re: Duplicate line items in the journal entry for advance...
entry.content:
Hello @AlvaroFernandezMorales ,

-In SAP S/4HANA Cloud AFCV, journal entries often show two lines: one with the actual FX gain/loss and one with zero amounts.
-The zero line is standard system behavior, created for line item structure, numbering, and reporting consistency.
-Only the non-zero line affects GL balances; the zero line has no accounting impact.
-No action is required; for reporting, you can ignore or filter out zero lines.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: From Complexity to Clarity: How Clean Data Fuels Success of Generative AI in E-Commerce
entry.content:
Introduction

Our interactions and shopping habits are being transformed by generative artificial intelligence. A combination of generative AI and e-commerce is solving long-standing challenges in product discovery, accessing information about products, and interacting with agents to make informed purchases. In this process, visual media, such as images, play an important role.

One of the main reasons for the success of generative AI in e-commerce is data quality. When we discuss data quality, we refer to the quality of product content, visual media, and the documentation that provides details

about the products, such as installation guides, warranty information, and service agreements. Integrity and cleanliness of these data are crucial for the successful implementation of AI in e-commerce.

In order to succeed in eCommerce, businesses must focus on data cleanliness and establish effective data management practices. Then, businesses can ensure AI features deliver exceptional value to their customers to the fullest extent possible.

Enriched Content Boosts Business Value

The quality of data and content is the key to achieving our Gen AI mission. The enrichment of product content improves customer experience and conversion rates. The accuracy and detail of the product contents, visual media and documents are playing a vital role in the customer purchasing process.

Product discovery is based on quality content. Businesses and marketing teams need to ensure that product content enrichment includes comprehensive core attributes, product tags, a quick summary overview, a detailed description, and high-quality visuals. The enrichment process should also establish links to product-related documents, covering product and service questions and clarifications.

High-quality structured data is the backbone of the e-commerce ecosystem and the building block for search, visual search, SEO, AI-driven personalization, and virtual shopping agents.

Driving Richer Product Experiences through SAP Commerce Content Enrichment

Creating high-quality, customer-ready product content remains a significant challenge for many enterprises.

  • Fragmented Data Sources: Product information is often aggregated from multiple enterprise systems‚Äîsuch as SAP S/4HANA, Enterprise PIM, or third-party repositories‚Äîthat are not optimized for customer-facing use. This results in inconsistencies and requires additional transformation before publishing.

  • Inconsistent Media Quality: Visual assets like images, videos, and other media elements are essential for rich product experiences. However, the available content often lacks the required quality, consistency, or relevance to effectively engage customers.

  • Incomplete Customer Context: Standard product details such as name, summary, and description often fail to address deeper customer questions during the buying journey. Valuable supporting information‚Äîsuch as warranty details, training guides, or service manuals‚Äîtypically resides in disconnected systems and is not readily accessible through the commerce platform.

To deliver a seamless and informed buying experience, organizations must ensure that product content is complete, consistent, and connected across all enterprise systems and digital touchpoints.

E-commerce AI is significantly enhanced by improving the quality of data, enabling precise predictions, informed decisions, and enhanced customer experiences that ultimately drive business growth.

Components of Data Quality Critical for E-commerce AI

Accuracy: Accurate data is crucial to preventing misleading AI results.

Completeness: Incomplete or missing data can lead to biased AI conclusions.

Consistency: All touchpoints should adhere to uniform data standards to prevent confusion and errors.

Timeliness: Up-to-date data is absolutely necessary to respond to market dynamics and customer behavior.

Relevance: In order to maximize the effectiveness of AI, data should be directly related to the context of e-commerce.

The data enrichment capabilities in SAP Commerce Cloud, along with the Joule Premium for CX (formerly known as the CX AI toolkit), are designed to enhance and optimize the data you manage for a more personalized and impactful customer experience.

Joule Premium for CX streamlines Commerce back-office operations by automatically extracting and enhancing product information using existing descriptions, images, and insights. This process generates engaging and consistent product data while improving merchandising and elevating the catalog with a cohesive brand voice.

 

Joule Premium for CX brings together a suite of intelligent tools designed to enhance product content quality and streamline the data enrichment process through automation. These four features enable business team to improve the quality of product data using Joule Premium for CX.

Generate Product Attributes and Values

Product tagging utilizes media and product descriptions to generate, translate, and maintain comprehensive attribute sets automatically and publish it. With the solution, rich, consistent product data can be maintained across all channels without manual intervention

Generate product descriptions

The Product Description Generation feature leverages intelligent automation to create rich, engaging product descriptions, using predefined product tags and media content in the desired language. It ensures consistency and localization across markets while synchronizing the finalized descriptions with SAP Commerce Cloud

Image generation and improving the image

Joule Premium for CX will use product information such as description, tags and documents to generate visual media (images for the product). It also improves the quality of the images by resizing the resolution, adding background etc.

Catalog Optimization Agent

Catalog Optimization Agent automates creating product descriptions and tagging of the products and publishing them automatically or after manual review in product content management. 

As Catalog Optimization Agent continually reviews product descriptions, attributes, and translations against predefined quality standards, it provides actionable recommendations for improving catalog quality. The agent ensures consistent product information across all supported languages and enhances product discoverability by optimizing attributes.

Improving data quality with Joule Premium for CX significantly enhances customer experience and conversion rates. Below are the customer experience features powered by Joule Premium for CX.

Conclusion: 

 It is the purpose of this article to discuss the importance of Data Quality in AI missions, as well as how it improves business efficiency and customer satisfaction. Before we embark on our AI mission, this may be helpful for performing an initial analysis of data and planning for data quality improvement. For more information, please consult the resources listed above and for more information, please contact your SAP representative. Thank you.

Enablement Resources

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Data Migration Using Parallel Processing in CDS View.
entry.content:
Introduction:

Migrating data is a key part of moving to SAP S/4HANA. When dealing with large datasets from older systems, it's important to migrate them effectively. In this blog, we'll look at how to leverage Parallel Processing in CDS Views to enhance the data migration process.

Business Scenario: 

We're moving sales orders from an old system into the target table [zsodet_target].  We pull the data using a CDS view [ ZSALESDATA_MIGRATION_USINGPP] and handle it with AMDP logic. To speed things up, we break the migration into date ranges and run them in parallel using destination groups.

Steps for Implementation: 

1. Create Source and Target Tables: 

a.  Source Table: ZSODET_LEGACY(Sales Data Source Table).

Entries of legacy table.

 

b. Target Table: ZSODET_TARGET(Sales data target table) - Initially it doesn't have any record, the data will be migrated from legacy table. 

 

2.  Create a CDS View:  The CDS view "ZSALESDATA_MIGRATION_USINGPP" is designed to access old sales data in a modular, secure, and efficient manner ‚Äî particularly when filtered by date ranges ‚Äî prior to its migration to the S/4HANA system.

Purpose of the CDS View

Feature Purpose
EncapsulationEncapsulates the logic to read only relevant legacy data (e.g., only for given date ranges)ReusabilityMakes the selection logic reusable across AMDP methods, reports, and moreSecurity & ReadabilityCDS views are clearer, safer, and easier to optimize than raw SELECT statementsIntegration with AMDPAMDP can easily consume CDS entities for fast, pushdown-enabled data processing in HANA

 

 

Parallel Processing Logic:

 To achieve parallel processing, we will use AMDP (ABAP Managed Database Procedures) along with the above CDS view for high performance and complex data processing directly in HANA ‚Äî instead of slow ABAP logic. It runs entirely on the HANA DB, not in ABAP layer ‚Äî so it's much faster.

AMDP:

3. Create Remote-Enabled FM:   Wraps AMDP method in a RFC-enabled FM for remote execution.

4.  Create Server Group (RFC Destination Group):

Purpose:  Server groups allow ABAP programs to run function modules in parallel across multiple application servers using CALL FUNCTION->STARTING NEW TASK -> DESTINATION IN GROUP.

Steps for creating server group:

  •  Go to Transaction: RZ12
  • Click on create assignment
  • Give the server group and instance name
  • Give the properties of the instance and click on Copy.
  • Server group will be created and check the server group status.
  • Distribute workload (for parallel execution)

5. Purpose of the Report Program

  • Dividing the Data: It breaks down the entire dataset (like sales orders) into smaller, more manageable pieces based on date ranges that the user can set. Starting Parallel Tasks: For every piece, the report kicks off a remote-enabled function module using STARTING NEW TASK, which lets multiple tasks run at the same time, greatly boosting performance.

  • Monitoring Tasks and Handling Completion: It keeps an eye on each parallel task and makes sure everything is in sync by waiting for all tasks to finish before wrapping up the process.

  • Enhanced Efficiency and Runtime: By using parallel processing, the report cuts down the total migration time and makes better use of system resources.

    • Status Output
      Once all chunks are processed, the report provides confirmation that the data migration has been successfully completed.

     

     

  • Now, check the target table to see the migrated data from legacy table.

    Thanks.

entry.title: Rap: Excel Upload and Download Excel using Rap only
entry.content:
In this blog, we‚Äôll create a simple app to upload and download Excel files, manage their statuses, and update child entities automatically  all in one flow. We‚Äôll learn how to store, process, and manage Excel data seamlessly within SAP  using CDS views, behavior definitions, and XCO APIs.

This blog documents the implementation of a RAP-based app that supports 

  • Excel file upload with validation and parsing
  • Template download for structured data entry
  • Dynamic status management and UI control
  • Association handling between parent and child entities

To enable file uploads in RAP, the following annotation is crucial:

 @Semantics.largeObject : {
      mimeType: 'Mimetype',
      fileName: 'Filename',
      acceptableMimeTypes: [ 'application/vnd.ms excel',
     'application/vnd.openxmlformats-officedocument.spreadsheetml.sheet'],
      contentDispositionPreference: #ATTACHMENT
      }

Lets Dive in the detailed steps :
1.  Create Database

Parent Database table : ZT2123_USER

This table stores attachment file details

@EndUserText.label : 'User Data'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #EXTENSIBLE_ANY
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zt2123_user {
  key client            : abap.clnt not null;
  key emp_id            : abap.numc(8) not null;
  key dev_id            : abap.char(30) not null;
  dev_description       : abap.char(100);
  attachment            : abap.rawstring(0);
  mimetype              : abap.char(128);
  filename              : abap.char(128);
  file_status           : abap.char(50);
  template_status       : abap.char(50);
  local_created_by      : abp_creation_user;
  local_created_at      : abp_creation_tstmpl;
  local_last_changed_by : abp_locinst_lastchange_user;
  local_last_changed_at : abp_locinst_lastchange_tstmpl;
  last_changed_at       : abp_lastchange_tstmpl;
}

Child Database table : ZT2123_USER_DEV

@EndUserText.label : 'user development objects'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #EXTENSIBLE_ANY
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #ALLOWED
define table zt2123_user_dev {
  key client    : abap.clnt not null;
  key emp_id    : abap.numc(8) not null;
  key dev_id    : abap.char(30) not null;
  key serial_no : abap.int4 not null;
  object_type   : abap.char(50) not null;
  object_name   : abap.char(80);
}

 CDS objects 

2. Creating Interface View 

Parent Interface View : ZI_2123_USER

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'user details'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define root view entity zi_2123_user
  as select from zt2123_user
  composition [0..*] of ZI_2123_user_dev as _UserDev
{
  key emp_id                as EmpId,
  key dev_id                as DevId,
      dev_description       as DevDescription,
      attachment            as Attachment,
      mimetype              as Mimetype,
      filename              as Filename,
      file_status           as FileStatus,
      template_status       as TemplateStatus,
      // to give color coding to file status
      case file_status
      when 'File Selected' then 2
      when 'Excel Uploaded' then 3
      when 'File not Selected' then 1
      else 0
      end                   as Criticality,
      case template_status
      when 'Present' then 3
      when 'Absent'  then 1
      else 0
      end                   as TemplateCrticality,
      @Semantics.user.createdBy: true
      local_created_by      as LocalCreatedBy,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.createdAt: true
      local_created_at      as LocalCreatedAt,
      @Semantics.user.lastChangedBy: true
      local_last_changed_by as LocalLastChangedBy,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.localInstanceLastChangedAt: true
      local_last_changed_at as LocalLastChangedAt,
      @Semantics.systemDateTime.lastChangedAt: true
      last_changed_at       as LastChangedAt,
      _UserDev 
}

Child Interface View : ZI_2123_USER_DEV

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'user devlopment details'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
define view entity ZI_2123_user_dev
  as select from zt2123_user_dev
  association to parent zi_2123_user as _User on  $projection.EmpId = _User.EmpId
                                              and $projection.DevId = _User.DevId
{
  key emp_id      as EmpId,
  key dev_id      as DevId,
  key serial_no   as SerialNo,
      object_type as ObjectType,
      object_name as ObjectName,
      _User 
}

 6. Behavior definition on Parent Interface view.

managed implementation in class zbp_i_2123_user unique;
strict ( 2 );
define behavior for zi_2123_user alias User
persistent table zt2123_user
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
etag master LocalLastChangedAt
{
  create ( authorization : global );
  update;
  delete;
  field ( readonly : update ) EmpId, DevId;
  field ( readonly ) LocalCreatedBy, LocalLastChangedAt;
  field ( mandatory : create ) EmpId, DevId, DevDescription;
  association _UserDev { create ( features : instance ); }
  // Logic to read excel data into associated entity ZI_2123_User_Dev
  action ( features : instance ) uploadExcelData result [1] $self;
   action ( features : instance ) DownloadExcel result [1] $self;
  // Change File Status During Creation of new record
  determination FillFileStatus on modify { field EmpId, DevId; }
  // Change File Status When file is selected
  determination FillSelectedStatus on modify { field Attachment; }
  // for reloading ui after data has been uploaded
  side effects
  {
    field Attachment affects field FileStatus  ;
    action uploadExcelData affects $self, field _UserDev.*;
  }

mapping for zt2123_user
    {
      EmpId              = emp_id;
      DevId              = dev_id;
      DevDescription     = dev_description;
      Filename           = filename;
      Attachment         = attachment;
      Mimetype           = mimetype;
      FileStatus         = file_status;
      TemplateStatus     = template_status;
      LocalCreatedBy     = local_created_by;
      LocalCreatedAt     = local_created_at;
      LastChangedAt      = last_changed_at;
      LocalLastChangedAt = local_last_changed_at;
      LocalLastChangedBy = local_last_changed_by;
    }
}

define behavior for ZI_2123_user_dev alias UserDev
persistent table zt2123_user_dev
lock dependent by _User
authorization dependent by _User
//etag master
{
  update;
  delete;
  field ( readonly ) EmpId, DevId, SerialNo;
//  field ( readonly : update ) ObjectType , ObjectName ;
//  field ( mandatory : create ) ObjectName, ObjectType;
  association _User;
  mapping for zt2123_user_dev
    {
      EmpId      = emp_id;
      DevId      = dev_id;
      SerialNo   = serial_no;
      ObjectType = object_type;
      ObjectName = object_name;
    }
}

Lets Break down the behavior definition.

Action buttons defined for Upload and download

feature instances as we want the button to be displayed dynamically .

 // Logic to read excel data into associated entity ZI_2123_User_Dev
  action ( features : instance ) uploadExcelData result [1] $self;
// To download excel 
  action ( features : instance ) DownloadExcel result [1] $self;

Determination to change file status, file selection status and template status

// Change File Status During Creation of new record
  determination FillFileStatus on modify { field EmpId, DevId; }
  // Change File Status When file is selected
  determination FillSelectedStatus on modify { field Attachment; }

Side effects to reflect uploaded data simultaneously when upload button is pressed.

  // for reloading ui after data has been uploaded
  side effects
  {
    field Attachment affects field FileStatus  ;
    action uploadExcelData affects $self, field _UserDev.*;
  }

Local handler class

CLASS lhc_User DEFINITION INHERITING FROM cl_abap_behavior_handler.
  PRIVATE SECTION.

    METHODS get_instance_authorizations FOR INSTANCE AUTHORIZATION
      IMPORTING keys REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR User RESULT result.

    METHODS get_global_authorizations FOR GLOBAL AUTHORIZATION
      IMPORTING REQUEST requested_authorizations FOR User RESULT result.
    METHODS uploadExcelData FOR MODIFY

    METHODS get_instance_features FOR INSTANCE FEATURES
      IMPORTING keys REQUEST requested_features FOR User RESULT result.

      IMPORTING keys FOR user~fillselectedstatus.
    METHODS fillfilestatus FOR DETERMINE ON MODIFY

ENDCLASS.

Method Implementation

Download Excel

 METHOD DownloadExcel.
    DATA: lt_template        TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zbp_i_2123_user=>gty_exl_file.

    DATA(lo_write_access) = xco_cp_xlsx=>document->empty( )->write_access( ).
    DATA(lo_worksheet) = lo_write_access->get_workbook(
        )->worksheet->at_position( 1 ).

    DATA(lo_selection_pattern) = xco_cp_xlsx_selection=>pattern_builder->simple_from_to(
                               )->from_column( xco_cp_xlsx=>coordinate->for_alphabetic_value( 'A' )
                               )->to_column( xco_cp_xlsx=>coordinate->for_alphabetic_value( 'M' )
                               )->from_row( xco_cp_xlsx=>coordinate->for_numeric_value( 1 )
                               )->get_pattern( ).

    lt_template = VALUE #( (
    emp_id = 'User Id'
    dev_id = 'Development Id'
    dev_desc = 'Development Description'
    obj_type = 'Object Type'
    obj_name = 'Object Name'
    ) ).

    lo_worksheet->select( lo_selection_pattern
        )->row_stream(
        )->operation->write_from( REF #( lt_template )
        )->execute( ).

    DATA(lv_file_content) = lo_write_access->get_file_content( ).

*  "Modify Root Entity
    MODIFY ENTITIES OF zi_2123_user IN LOCAL MODE
    ENTITY User
    UPDATE FROM VALUE #( FOR ls_key IN keys
       (
       EmpId      = ls_key-EmpId
       DevId      = ls_key-DevId
       Attachment = lv_file_content
       Filename   = 'template.xlsx'
       Mimetype   = 'application/vnd.ms-excel'
       %control-Attachment  = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
       %control-Filename   = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
       %control-Mimetype  = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
       ) )
    MAPPED DATA(ls_mapped_update)
    REPORTED DATA(ls_reported_update)
    FAILED DATA(ls_failed_update).

*    "Read Updated Entry
    READ ENTITIES OF zi_2123_user IN LOCAL MODE
    ENTITY  User
    ALL FIELDS WITH
    CORRESPONDING #( Keys )
    RESULT DATA(lt_User).
*    "Update File Status
    LOOP AT lt_User INTO DATA(ls_user).
      MODIFY ENTITIES OF ZI_2123_user IN LOCAL MODE
      ENTITY User
      UPDATE FIELDS ( FileStatus TemplateStatus )
      WITH VALUE #( (
          %tky                  = ls_user-%tky
          %data-FileStatus      = 'File not Selected'
          %data-TemplateStatus      = 'Present'
          %control-FileStatus   = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
          %control-TemplateStatus   = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
          ) )
          MAPPED DATA(ls_mapped_status)
    REPORTED DATA(ls_reported_status)
    FAILED DATA(ls_failed_status).
    ENDLOOP.


    "Send Status back to front end
    result = VALUE #( FOR ls_upd_user IN lt_User
                      ( %tky   = ls_upd_user-%tky
                        %param = ls_upd_user
                        ) ).

    IF ls_failed_update IS INITIAL.
   reported = VALUE #( BASE reported user = VALUE #( ( %tky = keys[ 1 ]-%tky
    %msg = new_message_with_text( severity =                                                   if_abap_behv_message=>severity-success
                     text = 'Template Available.' )

                                                                    ) )  ).
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.

Upload Excel Data

METHOD uploadExcelData.
    DATA: lt_rows         TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF string,
          lv_content      TYPE string,
          lo_table_descr  TYPE REF TO cl_abap_tabledescr,
          lo_struct_descr TYPE REF TO cl_abap_structdescr,
          lt_excel        TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zbp_i_2123_user=>gty_exl_file,
          lt_excel_temp   TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zbp_i_2123_user=>gty_exl_file,
          lt_excel_filter TYPE SORTED TABLE OF zbp_i_2123_user=>gty_exl_file WITH UNIQUE KEY emp_id dev_id,
          lt_data         TYPE TABLE FOR CREATE zi_2123_user\_UserDev,
          lv_index        TYPE sy-index.


    FIELD-SYMBOLS: <lfs_col_header> TYPE string.

    DATA(lv_user) = cl_abap_context_info=>get_user_technical_name( ).

    READ ENTITIES OF zi_2123_user IN LOCAL MODE
    ENTITY User
    ALL FIELDS WITH CORRESPONDING #( keys )
    RESULT DATA(lt_file_entity).

    DATA(lv_attachment) = lt_file_entity[ 1 ]-attachment.
    CHECK lv_attachment IS NOT INITIAL.

    "Move Excel Data to Internal Table
    DATA(lo_xlsx)      = xco_cp_xlsx=>document->for_file_content( iv_file_content = lv_attachment )->read_access( ).
    DATA(lo_worksheet) = lo_xlsx->get_workbook( )->worksheet->at_position( 1 ).
    DATA(lo_selection_pattern) = xco_cp_xlsx_selection=>pattern_builder->simple_from_to( )->get_pattern( ).
    DATA(lo_execute) = lo_worksheet->select( lo_selection_pattern )->row_stream( )->operation->write_to(
                                                                                   REF #( lt_excel_temp ) ).
    lo_execute->set_value_transformation(
        xco_cp_xlsx_read_access=>value_transformation->string_value )->if_xco_xlsx_ra_operation~execute( ).

    " Get number of columns in upload file for validation
    TRY.
        lo_table_descr ?= cl_abap_tabledescr=>describe_by_data( p_data = lt_excel_temp ).
        lo_struct_descr ?= lo_table_descr->get_table_line_type( ).
        DATA(lv_no_of_cols) = lines( lo_struct_descr->components ).
      CATCH cx_sy_move_cast_error.
        "Implement error handling
    ENDTRY.

    "Validate Header record
    DATA(ls_excel) = VALUE #( lt_excel_temp[ 1 ] OPTIONAL ).
    IF ls_excel IS NOT INITIAL.
      DO lv_no_of_cols TIMES.
        lv_index = sy-index.
        ASSIGN COMPONENT lv_index OF STRUCTURE ls_excel TO <lfs_col_header>.
        CHECK <lfs_col_header> IS ASSIGNED.
        DATA(lv_value) =  to_upper(  <lfs_col_header> ) .
        DATA(lv_has_error) = abap_false.
        CASE lv_index.
          WHEN 1.
            lv_has_error = COND #( WHEN lv_value <> 'USER ID' THEN abap_true ELSE lv_has_error ).
          WHEN 2.
            lv_has_error = COND #( WHEN lv_value <> 'DEVELOPMENT ID' THEN abap_true ELSE lv_has_error ).
          WHEN 3.
            lv_has_error = COND #( WHEN lv_value <> 'DEVELOPMENT DESCRIPTION' THEN abap_true ELSE lv_has_error ).
          WHEN 4.
            lv_has_error = COND #( WHEN lv_value <> 'OBJECT TYPE' THEN abap_true ELSE lv_has_error ).
          WHEN 5.
            lv_has_error = COND #( WHEN lv_value <> 'OBJECT NAME' THEN abap_true ELSE lv_has_error ).
          WHEN 9. "More than 7 columns (error)
            lv_has_error = abap_true.
        ENDCASE.
        IF lv_has_error = abap_true.
          APPEND VALUE #( %tky = lt_file_entity[ 1 ]-%tky ) TO failed-user.
          APPEND VALUE #(
            %tky = lt_file_entity[ 1 ]-%tky
            %msg = new_message_with_text(
                     severity = if_abap_behv_message=>severity-error
                     text     = 'One or more heading is incorrect !!' )
          ) TO reported-user.
          UNASSIGN <lfs_col_header>.
          EXIT.
        ENDIF.
        UNASSIGN <lfs_col_header>.
      ENDDO.
    ENDIF.
    CHECK lv_has_error = abap_false.

    DELETE lt_excel_temp INDEX 1.
    DELETE lt_excel_temp WHERE emp_id  IS INITIAL AND dev_id IS INITIAL.
    " Filter with current dev id details
    lt_excel_filter = VALUE #( ( emp_id = keys[ 1 ]-EmpId dev_id = keys[ 1 ]-DevId ) ).
    " excel data with  current dev id details
    lt_excel = FILTER #( lt_excel_temp IN lt_excel_filter WHERE emp_id = emp_id AND dev_id = dev_id ).
    IF lt_excel IS  INITIAL.

      reported = VALUE #( BASE reported user = VALUE #( ( %tky = keys[ 1 ]-%tky
                                                                        %msg = new_message_with_text( severity =
                                                                        if_abap_behv_message=>severity-error
                                                                        text = 'Trying to insert Invalid /Blank Values.' )
                                                                      ) )  ).
    ELSE.
      "Fill serial number
      LOOP AT lt_excel ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_excel>).
        <lfs_excel>-serial_no = sy-tabix.
      ENDLOOP.

      "Prepare Data for  Child Entity (UserDev)
      lt_data = VALUE #(
          (   %cid_ref  = keys[ 1 ]-%cid_ref
              EmpId   = keys[ 1 ]-EmpId
              DevId    = keys[ 1 ]-DevId
              %target   = VALUE #(
                               FOR lwa_excel IN lt_excel (
                                    %cid         = keys[ 1 ]-%cid_ref
                                    %data = VALUE #(
                                                     EmpId = keys[ 1 ]-EmpId
                                                     DevId = keys[ 1 ]-DevId
                                                     SerialNo = lwa_excel-serial_no
                                                     ObjectType = lwa_excel-obj_type
                                                     ObjectName = lwa_excel-obj_name
                                                  )
                                     %control = VALUE #(
                                                     EmpId = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
                                                     DevId = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
                                                     SerialNo = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
                                                     ObjectType = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
                                                     ObjectName = if_abap_behv=>mk-on

                                        )
                      ) ) ) ).

      "Delete Existing entry for user if any
      READ ENTITIES OF zi_2123_user IN LOCAL MODE
      ENTITY User BY \_UserDev
      ALL FIELDS WITH CORRESPONDING #( keys )
      RESULT DATA(lt_existing_UserDev).

      IF lt_existing_UserDev IS NOT INITIAL.
        MODIFY ENTITIES OF zi_2123_user IN LOCAL MODE
        ENTITY UserDev DELETE FROM VALUE #(
          FOR lwa_data IN lt_existing_UserDev (
            %key        = lwa_data-%key
          )
        )
        MAPPED DATA(lt_del_mapped)
        REPORTED DATA(lt_del_reported)
        FAILED DATA(lt_del_failed).
      ENDIF.

      "Add New Entry for XLData (association)
      MODIFY ENTITIES OF ZI_2123_User IN LOCAL MODE
      ENTITY User CREATE BY \_UserDev
      AUTO FILL CID WITH lt_data.

*    "Modify Status
      MODIFY ENTITIES OF ZI_2123_User IN LOCAL MODE
      ENTITY User
      UPDATE FROM VALUE #(  (
          %tky        = lt_file_entity[ 1 ]-%tky "keys[ 1 ]-%tky
          FileStatus  = 'Excel Uploaded'
          %control-FileStatus = if_abap_behv=>mk-on ) )
      MAPPED DATA(lt_upd_mapped)
      FAILED DATA(lt_upd_failed)
      REPORTED DATA(lt_upd_reported).

      "Read Updated Entry
      READ ENTITIES OF ZI_2123_User IN LOCAL MODE
      ENTITY User ALL FIELDS WITH CORRESPONDING #( Keys )
      RESULT DATA(lt_updated_User).

      "Send Status back to front end
      result = VALUE #(
        FOR lwa_upd_head IN lt_updated_User (
          %tky    = lwa_upd_head-%tky
          %param  = lwa_upd_head
        )
      ).
      IF lt_upd_failed IS INITIAL.
   reported = VALUE #( BASE reported user = VALUE #( ( %tky = keys[ 1 ]-%tky
 %msg = new_message_with_text( severity =                                                                 if_abap_behv_message=>severity-success
                       text = 'Excel Uploaded Successfully.' )
  ) )  ).
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.

File status

METHOD FillFileStatus.
    "Read the data to be modified
    READ ENTITIES OF ZI_2123_User IN LOCAL MODE
    ENTITY User FIELDS ( EmpId DevId FileStatus )
    WITH CORRESPONDING #( keys )
    RESULT DATA(lt_user).

    "Update File Status
    LOOP AT lt_user INTO DATA(ls_user).
      MODIFY ENTITIES OF ZI_2123_User IN LOCAL MODE
      ENTITY User
      UPDATE FIELDS ( FileStatus TemplateStatus )
      WITH VALUE #( (
          %tky                  = ls_user-%tky
          %data-FileStatus      = 'File not Selected'
          %data-TemplateStatus      = 'Absent'
          %control-FileStatus   = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
           %control-TemplateStatus   = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
          ) ).
    ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.

File selection status

METHOD FillSelectedStatus.
    "Read XL_Head Entities and change file status
    READ ENTITIES OF ZI_2123_user IN LOCAL MODE
    ENTITY User ALL FIELDS WITH CORRESPONDING #( keys )
    RESULT DATA(lt_User).

    "Update File Status
    LOOP AT lt_User INTO DATA(ls_user).
      MODIFY ENTITIES OF ZI_2123_user IN LOCAL MODE
      ENTITY User
      UPDATE FIELDS ( FileStatus TemplateStatus  )
      WITH VALUE #( (
          %tky                  = ls_user-%tky
          %data-FileStatus      = COND #(
                                    WHEN ls_user-Attachment IS INITIAL
                                    THEN 'File not Selected'
                                    ELSE 'File Selected' )
          %control-FileStatus   = if_abap_behv=>mk-on
          ) ).
    ENDLOOP.

    READ ENTITIES OF ZI_2123_user IN LOCAL MODE
  ENTITY User ALL FIELDS WITH CORRESPONDING #( keys )
  RESULT DATA(lt_User_updated).
    "Update template Status
    LOOP AT lt_User_updated INTO DATA(ls_user_updated).
      MODIFY ENTITIES OF ZI_2123_user IN LOCAL MODE
      ENTITY User
      UPDATE FIELDS ( TemplateStatus  )
      WITH VALUE #( (
                    %tky                = ls_user-%tky
                    %data-TemplateStatus = COND #(
                                    WHEN ls_user-Attachment IS NOT INITIAL
                                    THEN COND #( WHEN ls_user-FileStatus = 'File Selected' THEN ' ' )
                                    ELSE 'Absent'

                                     )
          %control-TemplateStatus   = if_abap_behv=>mk-on

          ) ).
    ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.

Global Feature Instance

to enable upload / download and create buttons dynamically 

 METHOD get_instance_features.
    READ ENTITIES OF zi_2123_user IN LOCAL MODE ENTITY User
    FIELDS ( EmpId DevId FileStatus TemplateStatus ) WITH CORRESPONDING #( keys )
    RESULT DATA(lt_users) FAILED failed.


    result = VALUE #( FOR user IN lt_users
                      LET uploadBtn = COND #( WHEN user-FileStatus = 'File Selected'
                                             THEN if_abap_behv=>fc-o-enabled
                                             ELSE if_abap_behv=>fc-o-disabled )
                         DownloadTemplate = COND #( WHEN user-TemplateStatus = 'Absent'
                                             THEN if_abap_behv=>fc-o-enabled
                                             ELSE if_abap_behv=>fc-o-disabled )
                      IN
                                            ( %tky = user-%tky
                                             %assoc-_UserDev = if_abap_behv=>fc-o-disabled
                                             %action-uploadExcelData = uploadBtn
                                             %action-DownloadExcel = DownloadTemplate
                                            ) ).

  ENDMETHOD.

now our app is ready . Lets create one record and see

we can see initially that Template is absent   and no file is selected.

Lets Download Template . We can see template.xlsx  now exists in attachment and template status changes to Present and download excel button disappears as template exist .  Remove the the template and you can see download button again .
Also file not selected as this is empty file . If you remove and upload it again , status will change to File selected. 

Download Template with predefined header

 Fill the excel . Make sure user id and development id should match with the record where you will upload data. Other wise it will throw error.

Choose the filled  file and you can see upload excel button appears.

Press upload and data will be reflected.

Hope this will be helpful.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Data Migration Using Parallel Processing in CDS View.
entry.content:
Steps for Implementation: 

1. Create Source and Target Tables: 

a.  Source Table: ZSODET_LEGACY(Sales Data Source Table).

Entries of legacy table.

b. Target Table: ZSODET_TARGET(Sales data target table) - Initially it doesn't have any record, the data will be migrated from legacy table. 

 

 

2.  Create a CDS View:  The CDS view "ZSALESDATA_MIGRATION_USINGPP" is designed to access old sales data in a modular, secure, and efficient manner ‚Äî particularly when filtered by date ranges ‚Äî prior to its migration to the S/4HANA system.

Purpose of the CDS View

Feature Purpose
EncapsulationEncapsulates the logic to read only relevant legacy data (e.g., only for given date ranges)ReusabilityMakes the selection logic reusable across AMDP methods, reports, and moreSecurity & ReadabilityCDS views are clearer, safer, and easier to optimize than raw SELECT statementsIntegration with AMDPAMDP can easily consume CDS entities for fast, pushdown-enabled data processing in HANA

 

 

Parallel Processing Logic:

 To achieve parallel processing, we will use AMDP (ABAP Managed Database Procedures) along with the above CDS view for high performance and complex data processing directly in HANA ‚Äî instead of slow ABAP logic. It runs entirely on the HANA DB, not in ABAP layer ‚Äî so it's much faster.

AMDP:

 

3. Create Remote-Enabled FM:   Wraps AMDP method in a RFC-enabled FM for remote execution.

4.  Create Server Group (RFC Destination Group):

Purpose:  Server groups allow ABAP programs to run function modules in parallel across multiple application servers using CALL FUNCTION->STARTING NEW TASK -> DESTINATION IN GROUP.

Steps for creating server group:

  •  Go to Transaction: RZ12
    • Click on create assignment
    • Give the server group and instance name
    • Give the properties of the instance and click on Copy.
    • Server group will be created and check the server group status.
    • Distribute workload (for parallel execution)

    5. Purpose of the Report Program

    • Dividing the Data: It breaks down the entire dataset (like sales orders) into smaller, more manageable pieces based on date ranges that the user can set. Starting Parallel Tasks: For every piece, the report kicks off a remote-enabled function module using STARTING NEW TASK, which lets multiple tasks run at the same time, greatly boosting performance.

    • Monitoring Tasks and Handling Completion: It keeps an eye on each parallel task and makes sure everything is in sync by waiting for all tasks to finish before wrapping up the process.

    • Enhanced Efficiency and Runtime: By using parallel processing, the report cuts down the total migration time and makes better use of system resources.

       

       

       

      • Status Output
        Once all chunks are processed, the report provides confirmation that the data migration has been successfully completed.

       

       

    • Now, check the target table to see the migrated data from legacy table.

      Thanks.

entry.title: Need SAP IQ Community Guidance ‚Äì Trellix DAM Agent Installation Compatibility and Impact
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We are planning to deploy a Trellix DAM (Database Activity Monitoring) agent on our SAP Sybase IQ 16.1SP05 PL10  environment as part of an enterprise security requirement.
Before proceeding, we want to understand if anyone in the community has implemented a similar setup and can share insights or experiences regarding compatibility and performance impact.

Here are the key details we‚Äôve collected from the Security (DAM) team:

  • Tool Name & Version: Trellix DAM 10.2.0

  • Deployment Type: Host-based agent installed directly on the Sybase IQ server OS (no SPAN/TAP setup).

  • Working Mechanism:

    • The DAM agent operates entirely at the OS level, monitoring SQL activities from memory.

    • It does not connect to the database, create users, or modify any schema/configuration.

    • Monitoring is controlled through rules configured on the Trellix DAM GUI console.

  • Performance Impact:

    • The agent is lightweight, with minimal CPU utilization (normal for any agent-based installation).

    • No impact on raw or storage devices.

    • No downtime required during installation.

    • Real-time monitoring based on rule matching (no batch/scheduled jobs).

  • Rollback Option:

    • The agent can be stopped or uninstalled from the OS level without restarting the database.

We raised a support case with SAP OEM, and SAP clarified that SAP IQ does not certify or validate third-party monitoring tools ‚Äî compatibility and performance assurance are the responsibility of the DAM vendor.

However, before we proceed in production, we are seeking advisory inputs or best practices from the community on:

  1. Whether anyone has implemented Trellix DAM (or similar tools like Guardium / Imperva) with SAP IQ 16.1.

  2. Any observed performance overhead, configuration changes, or tuning considerations.

  3. Recommended IQ parameters or OS-level checks to monitor after agent installation.

  4. Any precautions, known issues, or SAP IQ processes that could be affected by third-party OS-level monitoring agents.

We are mainly concerned about ensuring that this integration doesn‚Äôt interfere with database memory, query processing, or I/O performance.

Any guidance, experience sharing, or reference documentation would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance,
Shahid Hawaldar
Associate DBA ‚Äì SAP Sybase IQ

entry.title: SAP ABAP - CDS Scalar Function
entry.content:
Creating custom functions in ABAP CDS 

A CDS Scalar function ( This feature is supported as of SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS 00 ) allows us to define a custom function directly on SAP HANA database using SQLSCRIPT and then reuse it in CDS view entities.

There are 3 parts in CDS scalar function ‚Äì

  1. A CDS scalar function definition ‚Äî this defines in and out parameters.

There will be one or many input parameters and exactly one output parameter.

Lets make this a CDS scalar function which will accept a date and returns weekday value.

2. Define the CDS scalar function implementation reference. This refer to an AMDP class and method having the logic. This part won‚Äôt have actual implementation.

It follows the scalar function name followed by _SQL

Click on next and provide an AMDP class and its method which will hold the implementation logic.

Next, lets create our AMDP class (ZCL_AMDP_SF) and a static method (get_weekday)

Here below is the Code snippet for AMDP Class and method

CLASS zcl_amdp_sf DEFINITION
  PUBLIC
  FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC .

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES if_amdp_marker_hdb.
    CLASS-METHODS get_weekday FOR SCALAR FUNCTION zcds_scalar_func.

  PROTECTED SECTION.
  PRIVATE SECTION.
ENDCLASS.



CLASS zcl_amdp_sf IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD get_weekday BY DATABASE FUNCTION FOR HDB LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT OPTIONS READ-ONLY.

    declare weekday_num int;
    weekday_num := weekday( input_Date );
    IF :weekday_num = 0 THEN result = 'MON'; END if;
    IF :weekday_num = 1 THEN result = 'TUE'; END if;
    IF :weekday_num = 2 THEN result = 'WED'; END if;
    IF :weekday_num = 3 THEN result = 'THU'; END if;
    IF :weekday_num = 4 THEN result = 'FRI'; END if;
    IF :weekday_num = 5 THEN result = 'SAT'; END if;
    IF :weekday_num = 6 THEN result = 'SUN'; END if;
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

 

In the implementation , we have added logic to find the number as per input date and using if else   logic we are providing 3 char weekday name for same.

 

To test this, we have to create another CDS view which will call this CDS scalar function.

 

Let‚Äôs execute the CDS view to get output of Scalar function.

entry.title: SAP ABAP Proxy Guide: Inbound, Outbound, and Debugging Step-by-Step
entry.content:
Introduction:-

In SAP ABAP, inbound delivery and outbound delivery proxies refer to the asynchronous communication interfaces used to exchange delivery data between SAP and external systems (like warehouses, logistics providers, or other SAP systems) using proxies (usually created from Enterprise Services or via SOA tools like SPROXY). Here's the breakdown: 

What is a Proxy in SAP ABAP:-

A proxy is an ABAP object generated from an Enterprise Service Definition (WSDL/XML schema). It allows the SAP system to send or receive messages in XML format, typically used in SAP PI/PO, SAP Cloud Integration, or other middleware scenarios. 

Outbound Delivery Proxy:-

Meaning:-

An outbound delivery proxy sends delivery data from SAP to an external system. 

Use Case:-

  • Notify a warehouse system about deliveries. 
  • Send outbound delivery details (items, quantities, shipping info).

Flow:-

  • Delivery is created or changed (e.g., in VL01N, VL02N). 
  • ABAP program or output type triggers the proxy class. 

The proxy sends XML data to the middleware or external system.

Inbound Delivery Proxy Meaning:-

Meaning:-

An inbound delivery proxy is used when SAP receives delivery data from an external system.

Use Case: -

  • A 3PL (third-party logistics) system sends inbound delivery confirmation. 
  • ASN (Advanced Shipping Notification) integration.

Flow:-

  • External system sends delivery data (in XML). 
  • Middleware routes it to SAP. 
  • SAP uses the inbound proxy class to receive and process the data (e.g., create/update delivery document in SAP). 

Technical Tools Involved:-

  • SPROXY: To view or generate proxy classes.  
  • SOAMANAGER: To configure endpoints (for web services).  
  • PI/PO / SAP Cloud Integration: Middleware for routing messages. 

Summary:-

Difference Between Inbound and Outbound Delivery Proxy:-

In SAP ABAP, SPROXY is a transaction code used to manage and generate ABAP proxies, which are used for communication with other systems, particularly via SAP Process Integration (PI) or SAP Process Orchestration (PO). These proxies act as interfaces, enabling data exchange between SAP systems and external systems using standard protocols like SOAP and HTTP.

Debug and Test Inbound ABAP Proxy:-

There are two methods to debug ABAP inbound proxies in SAP:-

  • Debugging using SPROXY test feature 
  • External Debugging 

Each method has it‚Äôs own advantages, disadvantages, limitations and use cases. But, using these two methods you can fully debug and test an inbound ABAP proxy.

Use Cases ‚Äì Troubleshoot using SPROXY:-

The internal SPROXY debugging method is useful if you need to debug variations of the same XML input message. This is a great way to test and debug SAP application processing without having to connect with the external system or PI/PO. Moreover, using this method ABAP developers can work independently to complete Developer Unit Testing (DUT) scenarios without integrating the interface end-to-end. 

Use Cases ‚Äì Troubleshoot using External Debugging:- 

We can use the external debugging method if you need to debug the proxy logic when messages are triggered by the external system or PI/PO. This will allow us to troubleshoot connectivity related issues, issues due to proxy version inconsistencies, character set issues, etc. Or if proxy messages are sent with attachments, you can use external debugging methods to identify attachment related issues. 

To use either method, you first need to identify the ABAP implementing proxy class. Additionally, you need proper authorization, proxy connectivity between ECC and SAP PI/PO completed, and proxy class generated/activated. 

How to Find the ABAP Proxy Implementing Class:- 

Before you can debug the ABAP inbound proxy, first you must find the ABAP proxy class. Then, you need to set a break-point in the appropriate method or ABAP code line in the ABAP implementing class. Break-point could be either a session break-point or an external break-point depending on the debugging method you choose. 

You can find the ABAP Proxy class in two easy steps:-

  • Step 1 ‚Äì Find the Inbound Service Interface and Namespace 
  • Step 2 ‚Äì Determine the ABAP Proxy class using SPROXY transaction 

Determine the ABAP Proxy Class Using SPROXY Transaction:-

Now that you have identified the Inbound Service Interface details such as name, SWCV, and Namespace, go to transaction SPROXY in SAP back-end system and navigate to the interface using the navigation tree. 

In the navigation tree select of SPROXY, select Source > ESR > SWCVs > SWCV > Namespaces > Namespace > Object Types > Service Providers > Service Interface Name. 

Navigation menu of SPROXY in SAP back-end system.

Double click of the Service Interface Name under the Service Provider view, to find the SAP ABAP OO Implementing class of the interface in ‚ÄúImplementing Class‚Äù field.

Another approach --> click on OpenObject ->provide the proxy's name and click ok.

Set a Session Debugging Break-Point in the ABAP Proxy Method.

Session break-point assigned in ABAP code.

Select ‚ÄúTest Service Provider.

Go back to the main screen of the SPROXY transaction after setting the break-point. 

To simulate the inbound proxy click on the ‚ÄúExecute‚Äù button on the main menu. This will trigger the ‚ÄúTest Service Provider‚Äù function of SPROXY.

Now we can see the display request in XML format. 

 

Define and Edit Input XML message:-

In the next screen, you can define the input XML message you would like to simulate. If you selected the option ‚ÄúGenerate Request Template‚Äù in the previous step, you can simply change the values of the XML nodes as required. 

To change the XML message generated by the system, click on ‚ÄúXML Editor‚Äù option in the header menu.

Give the appropriate field name and execute, we can see this in debug screen:-

External Debugging Steps:-

Most of the steps to debug inbound proxies using external debugging method are the same as debugging using SPROXY. For example, finding the service interface, proxy class are the same for external debugging as SPROXY debugging. But, there are two very important distinctions between the two different methods. 

To set up external debugging, additionally, you need to, 

  • Find HTTP system user.
  • Configure User-Specific Debugging Setting in SAP Back-end.
  • Set an external debugging break-point instead of a session breakpoint.

Step 1 ‚Äì Find HTTP System Username:- 

The first step is to find the HTTP system user used to connect the SAP system with SAP PI/PO. When the external system or PI/PO sends inbound Proxy messages to SAP, this user will authenticate the exchange of messages. We need this username to set the external debugging break-point in the next step.

Step 2 ‚Äì Configure User-Specific Debugging Setting in SAP Back-end:-

To configure the user-specific debugging settings open any ABAP editor and go to Utilities > Setting > ABAP Editor > Debugging.

Then set the user of Debug External Requests (RFC, HTTP) with the HTTP user we determined from the HTTP destination in PI/PO. 

Step 3 ‚Äì Set External Debugging Point:-

Instead of a session debugging point, set an External Break-point in the Proxy ABAP code. 

Conclusion:-

SAP proxies simplify integration by bridging SAP and external systems without handling low-level protocols. With a solid grasp of inbound/outbound proxies and the ability to debug using both session and external debugging, developers can design stable interfaces and resolve issues efficiently. This combination ensures smoother communication, faster troubleshooting, and more reliable end-to-end processes. 

Thank You__

entry.title: Understanding Shadow AI and Its Impact on Data Security
entry.content:
Hi community! This is my second post here, and I wanted to share a topic that keeps coming up in conversations with many IT leaders lately: Shadow AI. 

We‚Äôve all noticed how quickly AI tools have found their way into our daily routines. It often starts with small things: someone uses ChatGPT to summarize a meeting, another person drafts a report with Gemini, or a colleague asks an AI tool to polish a sales email. Most of the time, these actions come from curiosity or a genuine wish to save time and work better. 

But sometimes, we might be introducing risk when using these tools without IT oversight. 

A recent example that caught my attention came from the legal world. Some in-house lawyers at large companies were using public AI tools to draft contracts or analyze documents. One case described a lawyer uploading confidential merger files into a personal account just to meet a deadline. It sounds extreme, but it happens more often than we think... 

Of course, people don‚Äôt intend to break the rules or do something dangerous. They just want to get things done faster. Still, when you use an AI tool without reading its data policies first, you might be exposing sensitive information or allowing it to be used for unintended purposes. Once that data leaves the company‚Äôs ecosystem, no one can fully control where it goes or how it‚Äôs handled. 

This is what many are calling Shadow AI. It‚Äôs the evolution of Shadow IT. Years ago, employees installed their own software or used unapproved SaaS apps to get their work done. Now, it‚Äôs large language models quietly spreading across teams without IT even knowing. 

Why does it happen? Usually, as I mentioned, it‚Äôs simply because people want to be more efficient. When official tools are too limited or slow, they look for alternatives that help them. 

That‚Äôs why I believe the solution isn‚Äôt to block AI, but to guide its use. When enterprises make AI available inside secure environments like SAP, people can use it safely and productively at the same time. 

Imagine a legal department using AI built into their SAP environment to review contracts or summarize long documents. The team saves time, but everything stays within the company‚Äôs governance and data protection rules. The same idea applies to finance teams running forecasts or HR teams preparing reports. 

AI can help... as long as it happens in a trusted space. 

Shadow AI isn‚Äôt about people doing something wrong. It‚Äôs about people trying to do their best with the tools they have. The challenge for leaders is to give them the right environment to expermient. 

And that‚Äôs the beauty of it: SAP gives you a safe space to experiment with AI through its own suite of tools - Joule, BTP, and Datasphere. 

Thanks for reading! I‚Äôd love to know if you‚Äôve seen similar situations in your teams, or how your organization is balancing innovation and data protection.

entry.title: Send Email in SAP CAP After Deprecation of @sap-cloud-sdk/mail-client
entry.content:
üöÄ Introduction

If you‚Äôve recently upgraded your SAP CAP project, you might have noticed that the @SAP-cloud-sdk/mail-client package is now deprecated. This package was previously used to trigger emails from CAP applications via destinations on SAP BTP.

In this post, we‚Äôll walk through a simple yet powerful alternative using Nodemailer, a Node.js-based email library, to send formatted HTML emails directly from CAP services ‚Äî ideal for workflows such as failure notifications, approvals, or report generation alerts.

üß± Prerequisites

  • SAP CAP Project (Node.js-based)
  • Access to a Mail Server (Destination screenshot attached)
  • Basic knowledge of Node.js modules
  • Installed dependency:
npm install nodemailer axios @sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity

‚öôÔ∏è Step 1: Set Up Nodemailer in CAP

Create a utility file srv/utils/mailService.js and configure your mail transporter using the destination defined in SAP BTP.

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

This means your mail destination uses a client ID and client secret to fetch an access token before sending mail ‚Äî (Basic Authentication case we use username and password ).

const axios = require("axios");
const nodemailer = require("nodemailer");
const { getDestination } = require("@sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity");

async function sendEmail(mailService, to, subject, body) {
  try {
    // 1Ô∏è‚É£ Fetch destination details from BTP
    const destination = await getDestination({
      destinationName: mailService.destination,
    });

    if (!destination) {
      throw new Error("Destination not found.");
    }

    // 2Ô∏è‚É£ Extract required properties
    const host = destination.originalProperties.destinationConfiguration["mail.smtp.host"];
    const port = destination.originalProperties.destinationConfiguration["mail.smtp.port"];
    const user = destination.originalProperties.destinationConfiguration["mail.smtp.from"];
    const tokenUrl = destination.tokenServiceUrl;
    const clientId = destination.clientId;
    const clientSecret = destination.clientSecret;
    const scope = destination.originalProperties.destinationConfiguration["scope"];

    // 3Ô∏è‚É£ Get OAuth2 access token
    const tokenResponse = await axios.post(
      tokenUrl,
      new URLSearchParams({
        client_id: clientId,
        client_secret: clientSecret,
        scope,
        grant_type: "client_credentials",
      }),
      {
        headers: { "Content-Type": "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" },
      }
    );

    const accessToken = tokenResponse.data.access_token;

    // 4Ô∏è‚É£ Create transporter for SMTP with OAuth2
    const transporter = nodemailer.createTransport({
      host,
      port: Number(port),
      secure: false,
      auth: {
        type: "OAuth2",
        user,
        accessToken,
      },
      tls: {
        rejectUnauthorized: false,
      },
    });

    // 5Ô∏è‚É£ Mail details
    const mailOptions = {
      from: user,
      to,
      subject,
      // text: "text message" use this when you want to send only text message
      html: body,
    };

    // 6Ô∏è‚É£ Send mail
    await transporter.sendMail(mailOptions);

    console.log("‚úÖ Mail sent successfully");
    return "Mail sent successfully";
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("‚ùå Mail send failed:", err.response?.data || err);
    throw new Error("Mail send failed: " + err.message);
  }
}

module.exports = { sendEmail };

üì© Step 2: Create a Formatted HTML Template

Here‚Äôs an HTML mail template for a simple Hello Message:

export const simpleHelloMailTemplate = (recipientName) => `
  <p>Dear ${recipientName},</p>

  <p>
    This is a <b>test email</b> sent from the <b>SAP CAP Application</b> using Nodemailer.
  </p>

  <p>
    Best Regards,<br>
    Shahrukh
  </p>
`;

üß† Step 3: Trigger Email in CAP Event or Error Handler

Now call this mail utility in your CAP event handler whenever a workflow or process fails or requires a notification:

import { sendEmail } from "./utils/mailService.js";
import { simpleHelloMailTemplate } from "./utils/mailTemplate.js";

this.on("sendEmail", async (req) => {
  try {
    const html = simpleHelloMailTemplate("SRK");

    await sendEmail(
      { destination: "mail-service-destination" }, // your destination name
      "yourEmail@sap.com",
      "Hello Mail",
      html
    );

    return "‚úÖ Mail sent successfully!";
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("‚ùå Mail sending failed:", err);
    req.error(500, "Mail Not Sent");
  }
});

üîê Step 4: Secure OAuth2 Credentials

Since this setup already uses OAuth2 Client Credentials from the BTP destination, you don‚Äôt need to store or manage usernames/passwords. The client ID and client secret are securely stored within your destination configuration on BTP, and tokens are fetched dynamically at runtime.

Attached Destination screenshot for reference

‚úÖ No manual secret management required! Just make sure your CAP application is bound to the destination service instance so it can fetch credentials using the SAP Connectivity service.

üåü Result

Once implemented, you‚Äôll receive a well-formatted email notification like this:

Subject: Hello Mail

Dear SRK,
This is a test email sent from the SAP CAP Application using Nodemailer.
Best Regards,
Shahrukh

If you‚Äôve received this message, your mail configuration is working perfectly! üéâ

üß© Key Takeaways

  • @SAP-cloud-sdk/mail-client is deprecated ‚Äî use Nodemailer with OAuth2 for modern email handling.
  • No need to manage passwords manually; BTP destinations handle tokens securely.
  • Integrate HTML mail templates for clear and professional messages.
  • Ideal for CAP event-driven notifications and failure alerts.

üí° Conclusion

This approach gives you full control and flexibility over how emails are formatted, triggered, and secured within SAP CAP projects ‚Äî without relying on deprecated packages. It‚Äôs lightweight, production-ready, and works seamlessly on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry environments using OAuth2-based authentication.

üè∑Ô∏è Suggested Tags

SAP CAP, SAP BTP, Email Integration, Workflow Automation, Nodemailer, CAPM, Cloud Application Programming Model, SAP Developers
